overview_of_class: The concept of "the superfluous man" has become a common-place in Russian literary and cultural studies. We will examine the most influential theoretical formulations of the concept, and question its usefulness as an aid to understanding some canonical nineteenth-century texts.
name: Studies in 19th Century Russian Lit.
title: WCAS SLAVIC 436-0-1 Studies in 19th Century Russian Lit.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The concept of "the superfluous man" has become a common-place in Russian literary and cultural studies. We will examine the most influential theoretical formulations of the concept, and question its usefulness as an aid to understanding some canonical nineteenth-century texts.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Written: Three short (3-5 pages) papers; Choice of the following: a dissertation abstract; a syllabus; a conference abstract. Written assignments will be circulated and peer-evaluated in addition to evaluation by instructor

Oral: Each student will lead a class session

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Primary texts: Griboedov, Woe from Wit; Sergei Aksakov, Family Chronicle; Turgenev, "Hamlet and Don Quixote" and Rudin; Goncharov, Oblomov; Saltykov-Shchedrin, The Golovyovs

Secondary literature: A selection of studies of the superfluous man

Reference work: They Say/I Say: the Moves that Matter in Academic Writing, Gerald Graff and Cathy Birkenstein 3rd edition (WW Norton 2014) TO BE OBTAINED AND READ BEFORE START OF QUARTER

subject: SLAVIC
